entry.value: Welcome to the Rapid demo application. Here you will find a vast array of resources that can be used in your own Rapid applications. The purpose of this demo is to get you used to the different controls and actions available in Rapid, along with various ways in how to use them. With access rights to the Rapid Designer it is possible to see how each and every example has been arranged and gives an example of how you can lay out your applications as well.

This menu has been assigned as the start page, which can be set in the Rapid Administrator tool. As the starting page is a menu it is most useful to link to every other page in the demo, providing it makes sense in a logical order to do so.

In the normal flow of Rapid, a starting page can be set manually, and pages can be re-ordered in the Rapid Designer. If the Rapid application is of tihe form type then setting the start page is disabled, and you will have to use the page ordering within the Designer to determine page order. There are some instances in a form application where you may not wish for a page to be visible. In cases like this you can set page visibilty rules to help curve the page path. Page visibility rules can be set for pages outside of form applications, as you will see with the dialogue pages, however they are most commonly used for form type applications.

To start this demo off we are going to introduce you to a mobile friendly control known as the flow layout control. At first glance this control can seem quite intimidating, however it is mainly used as a responsive, interactive menu for options that can be stylised using CSS, glyphs and panels. By using the flow layout in this way you will find that it is possible, quickly and easily, to create an intuitive menu with items that are easy for users to navigate around. For the flow layout cell a minimum width can be set so that the elements inside can conform to a set standard and will move onto a new line when this width is met, avoiding cell clustering and squashed cells. If you find that your flow layout cells appear squashed together in the Rapid Designer clicking on the Save button will update their appearance.

page.htmlBody:
Rapid demo application

Welcome to the Rapid demo application. Here you will find a vast array of resources that can be used in your own Rapid applications. The purpose of this demo is to get you used to the different controls and actions available in Rapid, along with various ways in how to use them. With access rights to the Rapid Designer it is possible to see how each and every example has been arranged and gives an example of how you can lay out your applications as well.This menu has been assigned as the start page, which can be set in the Rapid Administrator tool. As the starting page is a menu it is most useful to link to every other page in the demo, providing it makes sense in a logical order to do so.In the normal flow of Rapid, a starting page can be set manually, and pages can be re-ordered in the Rapid Designer. If the Rapid application is of tihe form type then setting the start page is disabled, and you will have to use the page ordering within the Designer to determine page order. There are some instances in a form application where you may not wish for a page to be visible. In cases like this you can set page visibilty rules to help curve the page path. Page visibility rules can be set for pages outside of form applications, as you will see with the dialogue pages, however they are most commonly used for form type applications.To start this demo off we are going to introduce you to a mobile friendly control known as the flow layout control. At first glance this control can seem quite intimidating, however it is mainly used as a responsive, interactive menu for options that can be stylised using CSS, glyphs and panels. By using the flow layout in this way you will find that it is possible, quickly and easily, to create an intuitive menu with items that are easy for users to navigate around. For the flow layout cell a minimum width can be set so that the elements inside can conform to a set standard and will move onto a new line when this width is met, avoiding cell clustering and squashed cells. If you find that your flow layout cells appear squashed together in the Rapid Designer clicking on the Save button will update their appearance.

Mobile menu


page.name: 01_rapidMenu

rolesHtml.html:
Rapid demo application

Welcome to the Rapid demo application. Here you will find a vast array of resources that can be used in your own Rapid applications. The purpose of this demo is to get you used to the different controls and actions available in Rapid, along with various ways in how to use them. With access rights to the Rapid Designer it is possible to see how each and every example has been arranged and gives an example of how you can lay out your applications as well.This menu has been assigned as the start page, which can be set in the Rapid Administrator tool. As the starting page is a menu it is most useful to link to every other page in the demo, providing it makes sense in a logical order to do so.In the normal flow of Rapid, a starting page can be set manually, and pages can be re-ordered in the Rapid Designer. If the Rapid application is of tihe form type then setting the start page is disabled, and you will have to use the page ordering within the Designer to determine page order. There are some instances in a form application where you may not wish for a page to be visible. In cases like this you can set page visibilty rules to help curve the page path. Page visibility rules can be set for pages outside of form applications, as you will see with the dialogue pages, however they are most commonly used for form type applications.To start this demo off we are going to introduce you to a mobile friendly control known as the flow layout control. At first glance this control can seem quite intimidating, however it is mainly used as a responsive, interactive menu for options that can be stylised using CSS, glyphs and panels. By using the flow layout in this way you will find that it is possible, quickly and easily, to create an intuitive menu with items that are easy for users to navigate around. For the flow layout cell a minimum width can be set so that the elements inside can conform to a set standard and will move onto a new line when this width is met, avoiding cell clustering and squashed cells. If you find that your flow layout cells appear squashed together in the Rapid Designer clicking on the Save button will update their appearance.

page.title: Main menu
